MainClaim.text: "Descartes's claim that virtue is sufficient for happiness is not exactly true: more than virtuous action is needed to secure happiness."

Claim1.text: "Virtue is primarily about exerting ourselves according to our best judgment."

Claim2.text: "Happiness is about having a contented mind

Claim4.text: "The third condition in Descartes's account of virtue is based on the idea that we must distinguish between what is and what is not up to us."

Claim5.text: "Fulfilling the third condition protects us from the threats to happiness of desire

Claim6.text: "The third condition involves an intellectual insight consisting of three key components: the distinction between what is and what is not up to us

Claim7.text: "Descartes's reasons for downplaying the intellectual insight his account involves are unclear."

Claim8.text: "Descartes downplays the intellectual insight his account involves because he thinks that all of its three main components are innocuous in their ubiquity."

Claim9.text: "The three major features of the implicit premise make their presence acutely felt in Descartes's theory of the passions."

Claim10.text: "Descartes's moral thought forms a surprisingly unified whole."

Claim11.text: "Happiness is not the highest good but something that is supposed to follow from virtuous action."

Claim12.text: "Virtuous action involves two components: judging well and striving to act according to one's judgment."

Claim13.text: "The intellectual insight involved in securing happiness is multifaceted and requires a rather complex intellectual insight into virtuous action."

Claim14.text: "Descartes's reasons for downplaying the intellectual insight his account involves are unclear."

Claim15.text: "Descartes leaves a key premise implicit because the insight on which happiness (partly) rests appears much more self-evident to him than to us."

Claim16.text: "Our historical distance allows us to see a philosophical assumption which Descartes feels extremely comfortable operating on."

Claim17.text: "The Cartesian sage is certainly not far removed from her Stoic predecessor."

Claim18.text: "Descartes's conception of virtue is primarily about exerting ourselves according to our best judgment."

Claim19.text: "Descartes's view of happiness is about having a contented mind."
